TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Click on each apparatus/reagents to know its name or click on ‘continue button’ to start the experiment.
Click on any one of the inoculation site to proceed with the experiment.
A 9 day old or 10 day old embryonated egg is taken from the egg rack.
A high intensity LED torch is taken from the work bench.
The egg is then candled with high intensity LED torch. The viability of the egg is observed.The internal structures of the embryonated eggs are then noted.
The LED torch is then kept back in the bench.
A marker pen is taken from the table.
Air space, suitable inoculation site and location of eye of the embryo were marked.
The embryonated egg is the kept back in the rack.
A small piece of cotton is then taken.
The wash bottle containing spirit is taken.
Small volume of spirit is then squeezed into the cotton to make it wet.
The wash bottle with spirit is then kept back in the table.
The labeled embryonated egg is taken from the rack.
The inoculation site is then wiped with wet cotton.
A small hole is drilled in the inoculation site using an egg shell puncher.
The embryonated egg is then kept back in the rack.
1 ml syringe and needle is then taken from the table.
The needle is then attached to the syringe and the cap of the needle is then removed.
The bijoux bottle containing influenza virus is then taken from the rack.
The lid of the tube is then opened.
Using the sterile needle and syringe 0.1 ml of the viral suspension (inoculums) is withdrawn and the lid of the bottle is replaced.
The bijoux bottle containing influenza virus is then kept back in the rack.
The labeled egg is then taken from the rack.
The needle is then placed into the inoculation site (Allantoic membrane).
The Influenza viral suspension is then injected into the Allantoic membrane.
The needle is then taken back from the inoculation site.
notext
The biohazard box is then opened and the used needle and syringe is discarded.
The drilled egg shell is then taken from the table.
The egg shell is then discarded in the biohazard box.
A small piece of stationery tape is then taken.
The inoculation site is then sealed with the stationery tape.
The virus inoculated embryonated egg is then placed back in the rack and then used for further studies.
Click on any one of the inoculation site to proceed with the experiment.
A 9 day old or 10 day old embryonated egg is taken from the egg rack.
A high intensity LED torch is taken from the work bench.
The egg is then candled with high intensity LED torch. The viability of the egg is observed.The internal structures of the embryonated eggs are then noted.
The LED torch is then kept back in the bench.
A marker pen is then taken from the table.
Air space, the eye of the embryo and inoculation site was noted.
The embryonated egg is the kept back in the rack.
A small piece of cotton is then taken.
The wash bottle containing spirit is taken.
Small volume of spirit is then squeezed into the cotton to make it wet.
The wash bottle with spirit is then kept back in the table.
The labeled embryonated egg is taken from the rack.
The inoculation site is then wiped with wet cotton.
Carborundum disc is taken from the table.
The egg shell of the embryonated egg is removed from the inoculation site using the carborundum disc.
The inoculation site is then observed carefully.
The embryonated egg is then kept back in the rack.
1 ml syringe and needle is then taken from the table.
The needle is then attached to the syringe and the cap of the needle is then removed.
The bijoux bottle containing pox virus is then taken from the rack.
The lid of the tube is then opened.
Using the sterile needle and syringe 0.1 ml of the pox viral suspension (inoculums) is withdrawn and the lid of the bottle is replaced.
The bijoux bottle containing pox virus is then kept back in the rack.
The labeled embryonated egg is then taken from the rack.
The needle is then placed into the inoculation site(Chorioallantoic membrane).
The pox viral suspension is then injected into the Chorioallantoic membrane.
notext
The biohazard box is then opened and the used needle and syringe is discarded.
The removed egg shell is then taken from the table.
The egg shell is then discarded in the biohazard box.
A small piece of stationery tape is then taken.
The inoculation site is then sealed with the stationery tape.
The virus inoculated embryonated egg is then placed back in the rack and then used for further studies.
Click on any one of the inoculation site to proceed with the experiment.
A 9 day old or 10 day old embryonated egg is taken from the egg rack.
A high intensity LED torch is taken from the work bench.
The egg is then candled with high intensity LED torch,The viability of the egg is observed,The internal structures of the embryonated eggs are then noted.
The LED torch is then kept back in the bench.
A marker pen is then taken from the table.
Air space, suitable inoculation site and eye of the embryo is then noted.
The embryonated egg is the kept back in the rack.
A small piece of cotton is then taken.
The wash bottle containing spirit is taken.
Small volume of spirit is then squeezed into the cotton to make it wet.
The wash bottle with spirit is then kept back in the table.
The labeled embryonated egg is taken from the rack.
The inoculation site is then wiped with wet cotton.
Carborundum disc is taken from the table.
The egg shell of the embryonated egg is removed from the inoculation site using the carborundum disc.
The inoculation site is then observed carefully.
The embryonated egg is then kept back in the rack.
1 ml syringe and needle is then taken from the table.
The needle is then attached to the syringe and the cap of the needle is then removed.
The bijoux bottle containing Mumps virus is then taken from the rack.
The lid of the tube is then opened.
Using the sterile needle and syringe 0.1 ml of the Mumps viral suspension (inoculums) is withdrawn and the lid of the bottle is replaced.
The bijoux bottle containing Mumps virus is then kept back in the rack.
The labeled embryonated egg is then taken from the rack.
The needle is then placed into the inoculation site (amniotic cavity).
When the needle touches the embryo a thirst is made and the embryo move away from the needle. The Mumps viral suspension is then injected into the amniotic cavity.
notext
The biohazard box is then opened and the used needle and syringe is discarded.
The removed egg shell is then taken from the table.
The egg shell is then discarded in the biohazard box.
A small piece of stationery tape is then taken.
The inoculation site is then sealed with the stationery tape.
The virus inoculated embryonated egg is then placed back in the rack and then used for further studies.

1 ml syringe and needle is then taken from the table.
The needle is then attached to the syringe and the cap of the needle is then removed.
The bijoux bottle containing Herpes simplex virus is then taken from the rack.
The lid of the tube is then opened.
Using the sterile needle and syringe 0.1 ml of the Herpes simplex viral suspension (inoculums) is withdrawn and the lid of the bottle is replaced.
The bijoux bottle containing Herpes simplex viral suspension is then kept back in the rack.
The labeled embryonated egg is then taken from the rack.
The needle is then placed into the inoculation site( Yolk sac).
The needle is then placed into the inoculation site( Yolk sac).
notext
The biohazard box is then opened and the used needle and syringe is discarded.
The removed egg shell is then taken from the table.
The egg shell is then discarded in the biohazard box.
A small piece of stationery tape is then taken.
The inoculation site is then sealed with the stationery tape.
The virus inoculated embryonated egg is then placed back in the rack and then used for further studies.
